segment.source: Set up a geofence
segment.target: Set up a geofence

segment.source: Set up a Geofence in your app, and learn how to handle notifications in the foreground and background.
segment.target: Set up a Geofence in your app, and learn how to handle notifications in the foreground and background.

segment.source: Set up a geofence
segment.target: Set up a geofence

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: Set up a Geofence in your app, and learn how to handle notifications in the foreground and background.
segment.target: Set up a Geofence in your app, and learn how to handle notifications in the foreground and background.

segment.source: Tip To learn more about accessing location in your app, download the following sample from the Windows-universal-samples repo on GitHub.
segment.target: Tip To learn more about accessing location in your app, download the following sample from the Windows-universal-samples repo on GitHub.

segment.source: Universal Windows Platform (UWP) map sample
segment.target: Universal Windows Platform (UWP) map sample

segment.source: Enable the location capability
segment.target: Enable the location capability

segment.source: In Solution Explorer, double-click on package.appxmanifest and select the Capabilities tab.
segment.target: In Solution Explorer, double-click on package.appxmanifest and select the Capabilities tab.

segment.source: In the Capabilities list, check Location.
segment.target: In the Capabilities list, check Location.

segment.source: This adds the device capability to the package manifest file.
segment.target: This adds the device capability to the package manifest file.

segment.source: Set up a geofence
segment.target: Set up a geofence

segment.source: Step 1: Request access to the user's location
segment.target: Step 1: Request access to the user's location

segment.source: Important You must request access to the user's location by using the RequestAccessAsync method before attempting to access the user's location.
segment.target: Important You must request access to the user's location by using the RequestAccessAsync method before attempting to access the user's location.

segment.source: You must call the RequestAccessAsync method from the UI thread and your app must be in the foreground.
segment.target: You must call the RequestAccessAsync method from the UI thread and your app must be in the foreground.

segment.source: Your app will not be able to access the user's location information until after the user grants permission to your app.
segment.target: Your app will not be able to access the user's location information until after the user grants permission to your app.

segment.source: The RequestAccessAsync method prompts the user for permission to access their location.
segment.target: The RequestAccessAsync method prompts the user for permission to access their location.

segment.source: The user is only prompted once (per app).
segment.target: The user is only prompted once (per app).

segment.source: After the first time they grant or deny permission, this method no longer prompts the user for permission.
segment.target: After the first time they grant or deny permission, this method no longer prompts the user for permission.

segment.source: To help the user change location permissions after they've been prompted, we recommend that you provide a link to the location settings as demonstrated later in this topic.
segment.target: To help the user change location permissions after they've been prompted, we recommend that you provide a link to the location settings as demonstrated later in this topic.

segment.source: Step 2: Register for changes in geofence state and location permissions
segment.target: Step 2: Register for changes in geofence state and location permissions

segment.source: In this example, a switch statement is used with accessStatus (from the previous example) to act only when access to the user's location is allowed.
segment.target: In this example, a switch statement is used with accessStatus (from the previous example) to act only when access to the user's location is allowed.

segment.source: If access to the user's location is allowed, the code accesses the current geofences, registers for geofence state changes, and registers for changes in location permissions.
segment.target: If access to the user's location is allowed, the code accesses the current geofences, registers for geofence state changes, and registers for changes in location permissions.

segment.source: Tip When using a geofence, monitor changes in location permissions using the StatusChanged event from the GeofenceMonitor class instead of the StatusChanged event from the Geolocator class.
segment.target: Tip When using a geofence, monitor changes in location permissions using the StatusChanged event from the GeofenceMonitor class instead of the StatusChanged event from the Geolocator class.

segment.source: A GeofenceMonitorStatus of Disabled is equivalent to a disabled PositionStatus - both indicate that the app does not have permission to access the user's location.
segment.target: A GeofenceMonitorStatus of Disabled is equivalent to a disabled PositionStatus - both indicate that the app does not have permission to access the user's location.

segment.source: Then, when navigating away from your foreground app, unregister the event listeners.
segment.target: Then, when navigating away from your foreground app, unregister the event listeners.

segment.source: Step 3: Create the geofence
segment.target: Step 3: Create the geofence

segment.source: Now, you are ready to define and set up a Geofence object.
segment.target: Now, you are ready to define and set up a Geofence object.

segment.source: There are several different constructor overloads to choose from, depending on your needs.
segment.target: There are several different constructor overloads to choose from, depending on your needs.

segment.source: In the most basic geofence constructor, specify only the Id and the Geoshape as shown here.
segment.target: In the most basic geofence constructor, specify only the Id and the Geoshape as shown here.

segment.source: You can fine-tune your geofence further by using one of the other constructors.
segment.target: You can fine-tune your geofence further by using one of the other constructors.

segment.source: In the next example, the geofence constructor specifies these additional parameters:
segment.target: In the next example, the geofence constructor specifies these additional parameters:

segment.source: MonitoredStates - Indicates what geofence events you want to receive notifications for entering the defined region, leaving the defined region, or removal of the geofence.
segment.target: MonitoredStates - Indicates what geofence events you want to receive notifications for entering the defined region, leaving the defined region, or removal of the geofence.

segment.source: SingleUse - Removes the geofence once all the states the geofence is being monitored for have been met.
segment.target: SingleUse - Removes the geofence once all the states the geofence is being monitored for have been met.

segment.source: DwellTime - Indicates how long the user must be in or out of the defined area before the enter/exit events are triggered.
segment.target: DwellTime - Indicates how long the user must be in or out of the defined area before the enter/exit events are triggered.

segment.source: StartTime - Indicates when to start monitoring the geofence.
segment.target: StartTime - Indicates when to start monitoring the geofence.

segment.source: Duration - Indicates the period for which to monitor the geofence.
segment.target: Duration - Indicates the period for which to monitor the geofence.

segment.source: Step 4: Handle changes in location permissions
segment.target: Step 4: Handle changes in location permissions

segment.source: The GeofenceMonitor object triggers the StatusChanged event to indicate that the user's location settings changed.
segment.target: The GeofenceMonitor object triggers the StatusChanged event to indicate that the user's location settings changed.

segment.source: That event passes the corresponding status via the argument's sender.Status property (of type GeofenceMonitorStatus).
segment.target: That event passes the corresponding status via the argument's sender.Status property (of type GeofenceMonitorStatus).

segment.source: Note that this method is not called from the UI thread and the Dispatcher object invokes the UI changes.
segment.target: Note that this method is not called from the UI thread and the Dispatcher object invokes the UI changes.

segment.source: Set up foreground notifications
segment.target: Set up foreground notifications

segment.source: After your geofences are created, you must add the logic to handle what happens when a geofence event occurs.
segment.target: After your geofences are created, you must add the logic to handle what happens when a geofence event occurs.

segment.source: Depending on the MonitoredStates that you have set up, you may receive an event when:
segment.target: Depending on the MonitoredStates that you have set up, you may receive an event when:

segment.source: The user enters a region of interest.
segment.target: The user enters a region of interest.

segment.source: The user leaves a region of interest.
segment.target: The user leaves a region of interest.

segment.source: The geofence has expired or been removed.
segment.target: The geofence has expired or been removed.

segment.source: Note that a background app is not activated for a removal event.
segment.target: Note that a background app is not activated for a removal event.

segment.source: You can listen for events directly from your app when it is running or register for a background task so that you receive a background notification when an event occurs.
segment.target: You can listen for events directly from your app when it is running or register for a background task so that you receive a background notification when an event occurs.

segment.source: Step 1: Register for geofence state change events
segment.target: Step 1: Register for geofence state change events

segment.source: For your app to receive a foreground notification of a geofence state change, you must register an event handler.
segment.target: For your app to receive a foreground notification of a geofence state change, you must register an event handler.

segment.source: This is typically set up when you create the geofence.
segment.target: This is typically set up when you create the geofence.

segment.source: Step 2: Implement the geofence event handler
segment.target: Step 2: Implement the geofence event handler

segment.source: The next step is to implement the event handlers.
segment.target: The next step is to implement the event handlers.

segment.source: The action taken here depends on what your app is using the geofence for.
segment.target: The action taken here depends on what your app is using the geofence for.

segment.source: Set up background notifications
segment.target: Set up background notifications

segment.source: After your geofences are created, you must add the logic to handle what happens when a geofence event occurs.
segment.target: After your geofences are created, you must add the logic to handle what happens when a geofence event occurs.

segment.source: Depending on the MonitoredStates that you have set up, you may receive an event when:
segment.target: Depending on the MonitoredStates that you have set up, you may receive an event when:

segment.source: The user enters a region of interest.
segment.target: The user enters a region of interest.

segment.source: The user leaves a region of interest.
segment.target: The user leaves a region of interest.

segment.source: The geofence has expired or been removed.
segment.target: The geofence has expired or been removed.

segment.source: Note that a background app is not activated for a removal event.
segment.target: Note that a background app is not activated for a removal event.

segment.source: To listen for a geofence event in the background
segment.target: To listen for a geofence event in the background

segment.source: Declare the background task in your app’s manifest.
segment.target: Declare the background task in your app’s manifest.

segment.source: Register the background task in your app.
segment.target: Register the background task in your app.

segment.source: If your app needs internet access, say for accessing a cloud service, you can set a flag for that when the event is triggered.
segment.target: If your app needs internet access, say for accessing a cloud service, you can set a flag for that when the event is triggered.

segment.source: You can also set a flag to make sure that the user is present when the event is triggered so that you are sure that the user gets notified.
segment.target: You can also set a flag to make sure that the user is present when the event is triggered so that you are sure that the user gets notified.

segment.source: While your app is running in the foreground, prompt the user to grant your app location permissions.
segment.target: While your app is running in the foreground, prompt the user to grant your app location permissions.

segment.source: Step 1: Register for geofence state change events
segment.target: Step 1: Register for geofence state change events

segment.source: In your app's manifest, under the Declarations tab, add a declaration for a location background task.
segment.target: In your app's manifest, under the Declarations tab, add a declaration for a location background task.

segment.source: To do this:
segment.target: To do this:

segment.source: Add a declaration of type Background Tasks.
segment.target: Add a declaration of type Background Tasks.

segment.source: Set a property task type of Location.
segment.target: Set a property task type of Location.

segment.source: Set an entry point into your app to call when the event is triggered.
segment.target: Set an entry point into your app to call when the event is triggered.

segment.source: Step 2: Register the background task
segment.target: Step 2: Register the background task

segment.source: The code in this step registers the geofencing background task.
segment.target: The code in this step registers the geofencing background task.

segment.source: Remember that when the geofence was created, we checked for location permissions.
segment.target: Remember that when the geofence was created, we checked for location permissions.

segment.source: For more info, see Set up a geofence.
segment.target: For more info, see Set up a geofence.

segment.source: Step 3: Handling the background notification
segment.target: Step 3: Handling the background notification

segment.source: The action that you take to notify the user depends on what your app does, but you can display a toast notification, play an audio sound, or update a live tile.
segment.target: The action that you take to notify the user depends on what your app does, but you can display a toast notification, play an audio sound, or update a live tile.

segment.source: The code in this step handles the notification.
segment.target: The code in this step handles the notification.

segment.source: Change the privacy settings
segment.target: Change the privacy settings

segment.source: If the location privacy settings don't allow your app to access the user's location, we recommend that you provide a convenient link to the location privacy settings in the Settings app.
segment.target: If the location privacy settings don't allow your app to access the user's location, we recommend that you provide a convenient link to the location privacy settings in the Settings app.

segment.source: In this example, a Hyperlink control is used navigate to the URI.
segment.target: In this example, a Hyperlink control is used navigate to the URI.

segment.source: Alternatively, your app can call the LaunchUriAsync method to launch the Settings app from code.
segment.target: Alternatively, your app can call the LaunchUriAsync method to launch the Settings app from code.

segment.source: For more info, see Launch the Windows Settings app.
segment.target: For more info, see Launch the Windows Settings app.

segment.source: Test and debug your app
segment.target: Test and debug your app

segment.source: Testing and debugging geofencing apps can be a challenge because they depend on a device's location.
segment.target: Testing and debugging geofencing apps can be a challenge because they depend on a device's location.

segment.source: Here, we outline several methods for testing both foreground and background geofences.
segment.target: Here, we outline several methods for testing both foreground and background geofences.

segment.source: To debug a geofencing app
segment.target: To debug a geofencing app

segment.source: Physically move the device to new locations.
segment.target: Physically move the device to new locations.

segment.source: Test entering a geofence by creating a geofence region that includes your current physical location, so you're already inside the geofence and the "geofence entered" event is triggered immediately.
segment.target: Test entering a geofence by creating a geofence region that includes your current physical location, so you're already inside the geofence and the "geofence entered" event is triggered immediately.

segment.source: Use the Microsoft Visual Studio emulator to simulate locations for the device.
segment.target: Use the Microsoft Visual Studio emulator to simulate locations for the device.

segment.source: Test and debug a geofencing app that is running in the foreground
segment.target: Test and debug a geofencing app that is running in the foreground

segment.source: To test your geofencing app that is running the foreground
segment.target: To test your geofencing app that is running the foreground

segment.source: Build your app in Visual Studio.
segment.target: Build your app in Visual Studio.

segment.source: Launch your app in the Visual Studio emulator.
segment.target: Launch your app in the Visual Studio emulator.

segment.source: Use these tools to simulate various locations inside and outside of your geofence region.
segment.target: Use these tools to simulate various locations inside and outside of your geofence region.

segment.source: Be sure to wait long enough past the time specified by the DwellTime property to trigger the event.
segment.target: Be sure to wait long enough past the time specified by the DwellTime property to trigger the event.

segment.source: Note that you must accept the prompt to enable location permissions for the app.
segment.target: Note that you must accept the prompt to enable location permissions for the app.

segment.source: For more info about simulating locations, see Set the simulated geolocation of the device.
segment.target: For more info about simulating locations, see Set the simulated geolocation of the device.

segment.source: You can also use the emulator to estimate the size of fences and dwell times approximately needed to be detected at different speeds.
segment.target: You can also use the emulator to estimate the size of fences and dwell times approximately needed to be detected at different speeds.

segment.source: Test and debug a geofencing app that is running in the background
segment.target: Test and debug a geofencing app that is running in the background

segment.source: To test your geofencing app that is running the background
segment.target: To test your geofencing app that is running the background

segment.source: Build your app in Visual Studio.
segment.target: Build your app in Visual Studio.

segment.source: Note that your app should set the Location background task type.
segment.target: Note that your app should set the Location background task type.

segment.source: Deploy the app locally first.
segment.target: Deploy the app locally first.

segment.source: Close your app that is running locally.
segment.target: Close your app that is running locally.

segment.source: Launch your app in the Visual Studio emulator.
segment.target: Launch your app in the Visual Studio emulator.

segment.source: Note that background geofencing simulation is supported on only one app at a time within the emulator.
segment.target: Note that background geofencing simulation is supported on only one app at a time within the emulator.

segment.source: Do not launch multiple geofencing apps within the emulator.
segment.target: Do not launch multiple geofencing apps within the emulator.

segment.source: From the emulator, simulate various locations inside and outside of your geofence region.
segment.target: From the emulator, simulate various locations inside and outside of your geofence region.

segment.source: Be sure to wait long enough past the DwellTime to trigger the event.
segment.target: Be sure to wait long enough past the DwellTime to trigger the event.

segment.source: Note that you must accept the prompt to enable location permissions for the app.
segment.target: Note that you must accept the prompt to enable location permissions for the app.

segment.source: Use Visual Studio to trigger the location background task.
segment.target: Use Visual Studio to trigger the location background task.

segment.source: For more info about triggering background tasks in Visual Studio, see How to trigger background tasks.
segment.target: For more info about triggering background tasks in Visual Studio, see How to trigger background tasks.

segment.source: Troubleshoot your app
segment.target: Troubleshoot your app

segment.source: Before your app can access location, Location must be enabled on the device.
segment.target: Before your app can access location, Location must be enabled on the device.

segment.source: In the Settings app, check that the following location privacy settings are turned on:
segment.target: In the Settings app, check that the following location privacy settings are turned on:

segment.source: Location for this device... is turned on (not applicable in Windows 10 Mobile)
segment.target: Location for this device... is turned on (not applicable in Windows 10 Mobile)

segment.source: The location services setting, Location, is turned on
segment.target: The location services setting, Location, is turned on

segment.source: Under Choose apps that can use your location, your app is set to on
segment.target: Under Choose apps that can use your location, your app is set to on
